docs.lead_paragraph: The insurer St. Paul Companies said that a Georgia state court judge had thrown out an order suspending its license in the state over efforts to cut losses in its medical-malpractice liability business. The company said the judge, Gail S. Tusan of the Fulton County Superior Court, overturned the suspension ordered by the Georgia insurance commissioner, John Oxendine. The suspension came after St. Paul said it would not renew more than 1,200 policies up for renewal in June. St. Paul said its medical-malpractice business in Georgia pays out $1.79 in claims for every $1 in premiums it collects, compared with a nationwide claim payout of $1.40 for every $1.

headline.main: ST. PAUL SAYS COURT REVERSES SUSPENSION OF ITS LICENSE

docs.abstract: Judge Gail S Tusan throws out order suspending St Paul Companies' license in Georgia; suspension was ordered after company said it would not renew more than 1,200 medical-malpractice policies up for renewal in June (S)
docs.snippet: The insurer St. Paul Companies said that a Georgia state court judge had thrown out an order suspending its license in the state over efforts to cut losses in its medical-malpractice liability business. The company said the judge, Gail S. Tusan of...

docs.lead_paragraph: The unidentified man who became the first recipient of a self-contained artificial heart two weeks ago has a positive mental outlook and has shown some signs of improvement, his surgeons said here today. But the man, who received the AbioCor device on July 2, remains on a ventilator because he becomes tired while breathing on his own, and he has experienced minor complications like bleeding into his stomach, the surgeons said. They attributed the man's extreme weakness to the severe malnourishment and inactivity brought on by his months experiencing end-stage heart failure.

headline.main: Doctors Say Artificial-Heart Patient Is Improving

docs.abstract: Doctors report unidentified man who recently became first recipient of self-contained artificial heart has positive mental outlook and has shown some signs of improvement; say he remains on ventilator and has only minor complications (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: HOSPITALS across the country are struggling with an acute shortage of nurses, but the hospitals' problem is a big opportunity for a handful of nurse staffing companies. These companies recruit thousands of traveling nurses who typically agree to work in hospitals on 13-week contracts. Thousands of other nurses take temporary work for a daily rate, often through a local, mom-and-pop employment agency.

headline.main: Market Place; Nurse Shortage Puts a Premium on Staff Agencies

docs.abstract: Hospitals across country are struggling with acute shortaes of nurses, but hospitals' problem is big opportunity for some nurse staffing companies; Staffing Industry Report says hospitals paid $7.2 billion last year for temporary employees, mainly nurses; says spending on medical staffing is likely to increase more than 20 percent this year, to $8.7 billion in 2001 and $10.6 billion in 2002; Cross Country and AMN Healthcare, companies that dominate traveling nursing business, are planning initial public offerings (Market Place column) (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Re ''In a Shift, an H.M.O. Rewards Doctors for Quality Care'' (Business Day, July 11): While everyone welcomes an emphasis on quality care by health maintenance organizations, the socially conscious epiphany by some H.M.O.'s that has caused them to reward good care is such a 180degree paradigm shift in thinking that skepticism is hard to avoid.
docs.abstract: Dr James A Slater letter on July 11 article questions seeming effort by health maintenance organizations to reward doctors for quality care

docs.lead_paragraph: THE doctor on the line is very angry. What they don't understand, she says, is how hard she works, how many lives she has saved and how much it costs her to run an office. If they did, she said, her voice shaking with anger, they would never make the choices they do. The subject of her wrath might be managed care companies -- and certainly she hates them -- but actually, it is you.
docs.abstract: Money & Medicine column by Jennifer Steinhauer on doctors' anger toward patients who drop them with little reservation if their employer makes change in health plan; doctors say many patients can afford more than $10 co-pay they are used to in managed care, and they should realize they cannot get something for nothing; drawing (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Victoria Marie Caspar, a daughter of Frances and George J. Caspar III of Avon, Conn., was married yesterday to Matthew Aaron Eichler, a son of Susan and Thomas Eichler of Bear, Del. The Rev. Percival L. D'Silva performed the ceremony at the Roman Catholic Shrine of the Most Blessed Sacrament in Washington. Mrs. Eichler, 32, teaches art at Bishop Ireton High School in Alexandria, Va. She graduated from the Catholic University of America. Her father retired as the corporate secretary of the Travelers Corporation, the Hartford-based insurance company.

docs.lead_paragraph: WHEN Ursula Goebel of Newtown lived with her two children and husband, a doctor at Fairfield Hills Hospital, in a staff house there during the 1960's and 70's, she never dreamed the sprawling state psychiatric center would one day release all its patients and close its doors forever. A virtual community unto itself, the hospital campus was designed to resemble a scholastic institution rather than an asylum.

headline.main: Next Up for Newtown: A Plan for the Land

docs.abstract: Article on recent purchase by Newtown of 185-acre tract in heart of Fairfield Hills Hospital, now closed psychiatric center owned by state of Connecticut; town already owns 100 acres of former hospital land and new purchase includes more than million square feet of building space, which is likely to be used for town purposes, including municipal offices and school space; photos (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Jaysen Deacon stood in the middle of the sloping suburban front yard, partially shaded by a large maple tree whose branches were filled with five giggling playmates. Jaysen, 7, was looking down at his sneakers, suddenly shy. Thump! Four-year-old Luke Harris dropped to the ground, calling, ''Jaysen! Jaysen! Jaysen!'' He ran across the lawn and wrapped his arms around the delighted Jaysen. Luke's father, Joseph, came up from behind and completed the hug sandwich.
